abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is
            satisfactory, sustainability highly likely, and the
            institutional development impact substantial. Lessons
            suggest that in countries undergoing rapid state
            transformation, operations responsive to comprehensive
            institutional reform, and capacity building, will likely be
            more effective provided project design allows flexibility,
            linked to a clearly defined framework. And, the success of
            such integrated approach depends not only on political
            consensus, and commitment, but on a robust strategic
            framework, that capitalizes on a flexible technical
            assistance (TA), and capacity building. Moreover, during
            periods of state transformation, this strategy, focused on
            capacity building, when complemented by serial budget
            support operations, i.e., balance of payment support
            operations such as structural adjustment loans, can pave the
            way for increasingly sophisticated forms of support,
            including demand-driven, performance-based capacity
            building, and fiscal support. However, in-service training
            for civil servants, tends not to be aligned with the broader
            performance objectives of public institutions, with varying
            degrees of cost, and quality. But the advantage provided by
            demand-driven matching grants, such as those financed under
            the Training Funds component, encouraged government agencies
            to assess training, introduce service standards, and reduce
            unit costs by promoting competition. Further lessons suggest
            investments in basic infrastructure to meet start-up costs
            associated with local governance; decentralization of task
            management to allow linkages between project activities, and
            evolving reforms; and, closer focus to ensure coherence, and
            streamlined design to facilitate implementation.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Institutional Capacity Building will
            establish local institutional and human capacity to develop
            and implement public policy and support the growth of the
            private sector through: (a) support for the continuation of
            the Civil Service Reform; (b) assistance to the Government
            of Uganda in its decentralization program; and (c)
            strengthening the legal and financial accountability
            framework and institutions. The project will consist of five
            components: (i) central government capacity building; (ii)
            local government capacity building; (iii) legal sector
            reform; (iv) accountancy profession; and (v) training funds.
